results.notes:
Hi everyone. I’ve been looking at this spore for half a year and I have no ideas or insight into what fungi this could belong to. This is a recurring spore from flying squirrel/small mammal scat. I found this in 77 out of 119 scat samples I was looking at. Some specialists think this could be a macrofungi and claim it is often found in southern flying squirrel scat. However it could also be microfungi.
It’s this ovate small spore with a thick border inside. Sometimes there was a pinch point or attachment point at the apex. Here are some photos. All were this brown colour and measures on average to 10 × 5 um in size. I could provide more photos if needed.

results.notes:
Three fruiting bodies in grass/moss in a wet depressed section of our lawn. Specimens fruiting directly from moss beneath long grass.
NOT FRUITING FROM WOOD.
Cap: dark brown/gray-nearly black.
Stem: thick, not fragile, vertically striated at apex.
Odor: floral, like geraniums. NOT LIKE BLEACH.
Taste: mild. NOT SPICY OR ACRID.
Harvested all 3 specimens.
Spore printed a section of cap on glass slide for spore microscopy. Later mounted in Lugol’s for amyloid test.
Removed gill slice and mounted on a separate slide in KOH.
Microscopy:
Cheilocystidia: Broadly/Widely clavate ornamented with finger like projections at top/apex(see photos of work).
Spores: very small, smooth, mostly pip shaped but some are slender and nearly cylindrical in shape.(see photos of work).
Spore Print: white.
Spore printed slide mounted in Lugol’s solution.
Faintly amyloid in Lugol’s. Pale greenish/blue.
Dehydrated all specimens and bagged for herbarium collection/genetic record.

results.notes:

Compare the field photos also with 478413 and 517207 which also show a similar complexly interdigitate coral-like branching (about which I have no good clue).

results.notes:
Fruiting directly beneath Douglas fir on the edge of an Alnus rubra grove.
Odor: NOT LIKE GREEN CORN.
Odor is complex, like toasted cashews or faintly of peanut butter. Unique.
Cap: with abruptly conical/papillate disc. Dark brown at disc point. Waxy brownish yellow, radially fibrillose/striated. Thicker/waxier than P. sororium.
Stem: smooth, translucent. Lacks chevrons/scales of P. sororium. Slightly pruinose.
Stem is equal, lacks bulb.
Harvested a single specimen.
Removed portion of gills and mounted two sections in KOH. Images of my work included.
Cheilocystidia: variable. Cylindrical, clavate to widely clavate with numerous larger lageniform.
Basidia: both 2 and 4 sterigmate analyzed.
Spores: elliptical to kidney shaped, smooth, medium sized.
Dehydrated specimen and bagged for herbarium collection/genetic record.
results.location_name: Pioneer Park, Tumwater, Thurston Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
On a lawn under Norway spruce. A few stumps (tree type not determined) within 30 feet of where the fruit bodies were found.
Stipes with buried basal roots comprising up to at least 60% of the total length.
Caps dry, glabrous; diameters 5 mm to 13 mm.
Gills white, adnexed to nearly free to (appearing) free. The gills on the mature specimen had darkened edges.
Spores white; pip-shaped, 5-6.5 × 2.5-3.5.
This area last had snow on the ground about two weeks ago. The four nights previous to 3/26 had low temperatures above freezing.
Apparently growing from buried spruce cones.
results.location_name: Vosburg Neck State Park, Wyoming Co., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
Scattered on a wet open pathway through brushy overgrown field.
Caps strongly hygrophanous, diameters up to about 2 cm. Mostly moist and brown (labeled A), but a small patch of dry ones faded to off-white with thin brown marginal area (labeled B).
No spore drop. Spores found via smash mount in KOH; irregularly ellipsoid, many with one guttule, several small ones, or indistinct contents; 5.5-7 × 4-4.5.
Hymenial cystidia cylindrical to flexuous, some subcapitate (likely cheiclocystidia, as they were restricted to a small portion along the boundary of the smash mount).
results.location_name: Vosburg Neck State Park, Wyoming Co., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:

Spores from a thin spore drop, ellipsoid to truncate with a guttule or other rather indistinct contents; 7-9 × 4.5-5.5.
Hymenial cystidia cylindrical, flexuous, subcapitate.

results.notes:
A standing live sweet birch tree (Betula lenta) had multiple growths on it. They were not as prominent or black as the I. obliquus sclerotia that I see on yellow birch. Also, the interior context was not as vividly yellow-orange as I’m used to seeing; more of a brownish color.
KOH on interior context instantly black.
I have never previously found Inonotus obliquus on sweet birch (always on yellow birch here in NE PA).
results.location_name: Vosburg Neck State Park, Wyoming Co., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
On hardwood, I think birch, possibly poplar.
The younger-looking fruit bodies were flexible while still damp, but quickly became rigid after losing moisture. There had been some rainfall the previous night.
Pores on the young-looking ones not with elongated lacerated walls; surprised to see this during March.
Surface color cinnamon when fresh, becoming more purple-brown by the following morning.
Spores 7-10 × 2-2.7, too long for T. biforme.
I examined smash-mounts of the hymenium, but saw only a few objects that looked like encrusted cystidia entangled in hyphae. Found only one suspected cystidium that projected slightly; last photo.
Matches morphology for genus Trichaptum; spores significantly larger than expected for T. biforme, and pores walls not as elongated/lacerated.

results.notes:
Лиственный лес (преобладающие дуб, бук, тополь).Трутовики (2 сросшихся и 1 экземпляр отдельно) росли на мертвой гниющей древесине упавшего дерева, покрытого мхом, располагаясь неподалеку друг от друга.
Плодовые тела мясистые, пропитаны влагой, прикреплены к субстрату боком, и растут параллельно земле, ножек нет.
Цвет плодовых тел желтовато-бежево-оранжевый, пятнистый, с верхней стороны поверхность мелкобугристая, в нижней части расположен трубчатый слой светло-серого, беловатого цвета.
Ширина более крупного гриба в месте крепления достигает до 25 см, от центра к краю около 20 см.
Толщина в месте крепления к субстрату не менее 4 см.
По мере отдаления от места крепления к краям, толщина плодового тела уменьшается и к раю становится закруглённой.
Один из трутовиков имеет сросшееся из двух плодовое тело, располагающиеся друг над другом.
При боковом срезе (разрезается без труда) наблюдается чёткое разделение плодового тела на два цвета.
Верхняя половина плодового тела имеет изнутри однотонный оранжевый цвет, нижняя – трубчатый слой- беловатый, светло-серый цвет. Трубчатый слой имеет толщину не менее 2 см, уменьшаясь к краям.
В нижней части трубочки как волос, свободные, плотно к друг другу не прилегают, и срастаются между собой уже глубже в плодовом теле.
Запах не выраженный. Вкус неизвестен.

results.notes:
I had this picture for several years, I believe now that this is the same to https://mushroomobserver.org/482052?q=1oXBL and we got a sequence for that one.
These were growing near the path, cosmopolitan, near the riparian zone of the Boise river, growing on grass, needles and debris, close to junipers used as a fence.
The form of this mushroom is variable, being the caps flat, convex, unbonated or umbilicated, and as they mature the cap is depressed and the gills are more decurrent. The stipe is hollow. The colors yellow/brown to grey/brown.
Very common in the cold season.

results.notes:
I have seen this one before and I wanted to be sure on the identification. I did some microscopy to confirm.
At the base of the foothills, by the trail, near the path, with grass, on the open, on sandy soil and hard pack soil.
Cap blackish/brown, 4 cm, smooth or with fine fibrils, hygrophanus. Broadly umbonate, a little depressed around the umbo. Same wavy.
Gills adnexed, subdistant.
Stipe striated, lighter at the base, overall light grey darkening with age.
Odor and taste, mildly farinaceous.
Cheilocystida absent, pileopelis with some hyphae coursely incrusted.
Spores (7.8-9.13) x (7.2-8.3) isodiametric.
Basidia (33-34) x (8.6-9.4). Couldn’t tell if they have clamp connections or not.

results.notes: Found on log with white rot. Has a hard, woody, brown top with green to brownish-red edges. The bottom is soft-hard with a orangish-brown fertile layer containing many small pores with tubes. Grows shelf-like on wood with a hoof shape. One fruiting body attached, another broken off. The habitat is a deciduous forest (Muir Woods). Has a positive KOH test, observed from a color change to black. This polypore is in the Basidiomycete phylum.

results.notes:
Growing in the same location as observation 454185 and observation 454187. Outside of the Northeast corner of Kottman Hall. Growing abundantly under the soil at the base of a Tilia sp. results.notes:
Large fruiting in a newly developed neighborhood/construction site. Construction began here Summer 2022. Recorded the location and returned again today(4/14/23) to see if any flushes had begun. Abundant fruiting surrounding a newly installed lamppost/street lamp(installed during construction Summer 2022.
Microclimate created by heat/vibration from lamps overnight. All fruiting bodies within 3 ft. of lamp post bases. We have noted this occurrence under lampposts with M. importuna for over 10yrs in new developments(most abundant flushes always beneath lampposts).
Note the ladder like/vertically arranged pits.
Harvested numerous mature specimens for culinary use(left even more to mature over remainder of Spring season). Dehydrating a single specimen for herbarium collection/genetic record with this observation.
results.location_name: Olympia, Thurston Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
These are among the first amanitas I see in the spring. They seem quite common in western MS April and May.

Cap is shallowly striate, occasionally with a larger patch of UV material, orangish red pulverulent material arranged around the disc (though quick to disappear after a rain). Color changes dramatically from creamy white in youth to a dingy red in maturity.

Stipe is flocculent.Same reddish material from cap is visible occasionally. Volva is more inclined to fold downward as the fruiting body is removed from the soil than other Lepidellas which seem to be more stout, rigid. Appearance of volva can be blocky or more ellipsoid. Just the uppermost limbs of the volva are generally visible in situ and sometimes it seems buried altogether.

Likes oaks, though I can’t rule out pines either. Grows scattered, rarely next to each other.
